Panels APIïƒ

Panel rendering and management for different visualization libraries.

Panel Managerïƒ

Panel Rendererïƒ

class trelliscope.panels.PanelRenderer[source]ïƒ

Bases: ABC

Base class for panel rendering adapters.

PanelRenderer provides an adapter pattern interface for detecting and saving visualization objects from different libraries.

Subclasses must implement: - detect(): Check if object is compatible - save(): Save object to file - get_interface_type(): Return panelInterface type - get_format(): Return file extension

abstract detect(obj)[source]ïƒ

Check if this adapter can handle the given object.

Parameters:

obj (Any) â€“ Object to check (figure, chart, etc.)

Returns:

True if this adapter can handle the object

Return type:

bool

Example

>>> adapter = MatplotlibAdapter()
>>> adapter.detect(matplotlib_fig)
True
>>> adapter.detect(plotly_fig)
False
abstract save(obj, path, **kwargs)[source]ïƒ

Save the object to a file.

Parameters:

  • obj (Any) â€“ Object to save (figure, chart, etc.)

  • path (Path) â€“ Base path for output file (extension will be added)

  • **kwargs â€“ Additional format-specific options

Returns:

Actual path to saved file (with extension)

Return type:

Path

Raises:

Exception â€“ If saving fails

Example

>>> adapter = MatplotlibAdapter()
>>> path = adapter.save(fig, Path('/tmp/panel'))
>>> print(path)
/tmp/panel.png
abstract get_interface_type()[source]ïƒ

Return the panelInterface type for this adapter.

Returns:

One of â€˜panel_localâ€™, â€˜panel_urlâ€™, â€˜iframeâ€™

Return type:

str

Example

>>> adapter = MatplotlibAdapter()
>>> adapter.get_interface_type()
'panel_local'
abstract get_format()[source]ïƒ

Return the file format/extension for this adapter.

Returns:

File extension without dot (e.g., â€˜pngâ€™, â€˜htmlâ€™)

Return type:

str

Example

>>> adapter = MatplotlibAdapter()
>>> adapter.get_format()
'png'

Matplotlib Adapterïƒ

Plotly Adapterïƒ

Panel Interfacesïƒ

class trelliscope.PanelInterface[source]ïƒ

Bases: object

Base class for panel interface configuration.

to_dict()[source]ïƒ

Convert to dictionary for JSON serialization.

Return type:

Dict[str, Any]

__init__()ïƒ

LocalPanelInterfaceïƒ

class trelliscope.LocalPanelInterface(format='png', base='./panels')[source]ïƒ

Bases: PanelInterface

Configuration for local file-based panels.

Panels are pre-rendered to files and served from the local filesystem. This is the default panel interface.

Parameters:

  • format (str, default="png") â€“ Panel file format: â€œpngâ€, â€œjpgâ€, â€œhtmlâ€, â€œsvgâ€

  • base (str, default="./panels") â€“ Base directory for panel files relative to display directory

Examples

>>> interface = LocalPanelInterface(format="png")
>>> display.set_panel_interface(interface)
format: str = 'png'ïƒ
base: str = './panels'ïƒ
to_dict()[source]ïƒ

Convert to displayInfo.json panelInterface format.

Return type:

Dict[str, Any]

__init__(format='png', base='./panels')ïƒ

RESTPanelInterfaceïƒ

class trelliscope.RESTPanelInterface(base, port=None, api_key=None, headers=None)[source]ïƒ

Bases: PanelInterface

Configuration for REST API-based panels.

Panels are served dynamically from a REST API endpoint. The viewer constructs panel URLs as: {base}/{panel_id}

Parameters:

  • base (str) â€“ Base URL for panel API (e.g., â€œhttp://localhost:5001/api/panels/my_displayâ€)

  • port (int, optional) â€“ Server port number (for display purposes)

  • api_key (str, optional) â€“ API key for authenticated requests

  • headers (dict, optional) â€“ Additional HTTP headers to send with panel requests

Examples

>>> interface = RESTPanelInterface(
...     base="http://localhost:5001/api/panels/my_display"
... )
>>> display.set_panel_interface(interface)

>>> # With authentication
>>> interface = RESTPanelInterface(
...     base="https://api.example.com/panels/display_123",
...     api_key="secret_key_123"
... )
base: strïƒ
port: Optional[int] = Noneïƒ
api_key: Optional[str] = Noneïƒ
headers: Optional[Dict[str, str]] = Noneïƒ
__post_init__()[source]ïƒ

Validate base URL.

to_dict()[source]ïƒ

Convert to displayInfo.json panelInterface format for REST panels.

Return type:

Dict[str, Any]

__init__(base, port=None, api_key=None, headers=None)ïƒ

WebSocketPanelInterfaceïƒ

class trelliscope.WebSocketPanelInterface(url)[source]ïƒ

Bases: PanelInterface

Configuration for WebSocket-based panels (future enhancement).

Panels are streamed dynamically via WebSocket connection.

Parameters:

url (str) â€“ WebSocket URL (e.g., â€œws://localhost:8080/panelsâ€)

Examples

>>> interface = WebSocketPanelInterface(
...     url="ws://localhost:8080/panels"
... )
url: strïƒ
to_dict()[source]ïƒ

Convert to displayInfo.json panelInterface format.

Return type:

Dict[str, Any]

__init__(url)ïƒ

Factory Functionïƒ

trelliscope.create_panel_interface(type, **kwargs)[source]ïƒ

Factory function to create panel interfaces.

Parameters:

  • type (str) â€“ Interface type: â€œlocalâ€, â€œrestâ€, or â€œwebsocketâ€

  • **kwargs â€“ Type-specific parameters

Returns:

Configured panel interface instance

Return type:

PanelInterface

Raises:

ValueError â€“ If type is unknown

Examples

>>> # Create local interface
>>> interface = create_panel_interface("local", format="png")

>>> # Create REST interface
>>> interface = create_panel_interface(
...     "rest",
...     base="http://localhost:5001/api/panels/display1"
... )

Examplesïƒ

Matplotlib Panelsïƒ

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd
from trelliscope import Display

def create_plot(data):
    fig, ax = plt.subplots()
    ax.plot(data['x'], data['y'])
    return fig

plots = [create_plot(group) for _, group in df.groupby('category')]

display_df = pd.DataFrame({
    'plot': plots,
    'category': df['category'].unique()
})

display = Display(display_df, name="matplotlib_example")
display.set_panel_column("plot")
display.write()

Plotly Panelsïƒ

import plotly.graph_objects as go
import pandas as pd
from trelliscope import Display

def create_plotly(data):
    fig = go.Figure()
    fig.add_trace(go.Scatter(x=data['x'], y=data['y']))
    return fig

plots = [create_plotly(group) for _, group in df.groupby('category')]

display_df = pd.DataFrame({
    'plot': plots,
    'category': df['category'].unique()
})

display = Display(display_df, name="plotly_example")
display.set_panel_column("plot")
display.write()

File Pathsïƒ

from pathlib import Path
import pandas as pd
from trelliscope import Display

# Pre-generated plots
plot_paths = [
    Path("plots/plot1.png"),
    Path("plots/plot2.png"),
    Path("plots/plot3.png")
]

display_df = pd.DataFrame({
    'plot': [str(p) for p in plot_paths],
    'id': [1, 2, 3]
})

display = Display(display_df, name="file_example")
display.set_panel_column("plot")
display.write()

Custom Panel Interfaceïƒ

from trelliscope import Display, RESTPanelInterface

# REST API panels
interface = RESTPanelInterface(
    base_url="http://localhost:5001/api/panels"
)

display = Display(df, name="rest_example")
display.set_panel_interface(interface)
display.write()

Supported Panel Typesïƒ

Static Imagesïƒ

  • PNG: Standard raster format (matplotlib default)

  • JPEG: Compressed raster format

  • SVG: Vector format (matplotlib with svg backend)

Interactive HTMLïƒ

  • Plotly HTML: Self-contained interactive plots

  • Bokeh HTML: Interactive visualizations

  • Custom HTML: Any HTML content

Panel Sourcesïƒ

  1. Figure Objects: matplotlib.Figure, plotly.Figure

  2. File Paths: Strings or Path objects to image files

  3. HTML Strings: Raw HTML content

  4. REST URLs: Dynamic loading from API

  5. WebSocket: Streaming panel updates

See Alsoïƒ

  • Display API - Display class configuration

  • Panel Types - Panel type guide

  • ../advanced/custom_panels - Creating custom panels
